awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  An Agent-based Self-learning Technology for Efficient Building Operations and Automated Participation in Electricity Markets
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR)  Phase I project is the capability to enable small- and medium-sized commercial buildings to operate more efficiently and facilitate their participation in electricity markets. It will result in energy consumption reduction in buildings, thus providing savings in electricity bills and lowering carbon footprints, without compromising occupant comfort. The proposed platform also enables revenue generation by allowing buildings to participate in ancillary electricity markets and respond to pricing or demand response signals from electric utilities. By integrating intelligent energy management and automatic demand response features to the traditional building operation, this helps electric utility companies to avoid/defer extensive upgrades of their electrical infrastructures, such as generation, transmission or distribution facilities, with the growing demand for electricity. The proposed software platform demonstrates the benefits of building automation to building owners/operators, and provides them the ability to cross-reference their buildings with best practices in building operations. It also bridges the knowledge transfer process between a small business and an institution of higher education by facilitating both sides to meet, work and exchange experiences with each other.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is built on an agent-based platform for building automation systems where advanced algorithms enable the software platform to be proactive and help optimize building operations. It can also perform fault detection, diagnostics and predictive maintenance, integrate emerging Internet of Things (IoT) devices and enable buildings to interact with the grid in an intelligent manner. Under the proposed project, a reinforced machine-learning algorithm will be developed that uses historical building energy consumption data and ambient conditions - including occupant preferences - to optimize building operations based on usage patterns of major loads and power sources in each zone of the building. Another major research contribution lies in novel algorithms that enable buildings to transact with the grid. These allow buildings to respond to system stress conditions and electricity price signals by automatically adjusting the operation of major loads and internal generating sources. Overall, the proposed software platform allows a building to optimize its operation, perform peak demand management during grid stress conditions, and participate in ancillary service markets.

por.por_cntn:
The overall objectives of this STTR Phase I project were two-fold.  The first objective was to validate the technical feasibility to reduce the electricity consumption (kWh) and the peak electrical demand (kW) in buildings while taking into account occupant comfort, using the open-architecture Building Energy Management (BEM) software platform, called BEMOSS®-Plus, being developed by the company.  The second objective was to quantify, in a simulated environment, whether resulting cost reductions were sufficient to justify the investment. 

The work carried out under this project was built upon an agent-based platform for building automation systems where advanced algorithms enabled the software suite to be proactive and helped optimize building operations. Accomplishments include development of reinforcement learning algorithms that use historical building energy consumption data, together with occupant preferences, to optimize building operations based on usage patterns of major loads in a building. Another major research contribution lies in novel algorithms that allow buildings to interact with the grid, which enable buildings to respond to system stress conditions and electricity price signals.

Using the validated building energy model developed during this phase of the work, simulation results indicate that 12-18% savings of building electricity consumption is achievable by adjusting thermostat temperature set-points during occupied/unoccupied hours.  Similarly, by adjusting the air conditioner and lighting load operation during peak demand hours, it is possible to achieve a 16-38% reduction in the overall building peak demand. Electricity bills can also be reduced by about 13% when adjusting building operation based on real-time electricity price signals.  By taking into account occupant preference in algorithm development, in addition to energy savings and peak demand reduction, BEMOSS®-Plus also offers building occupants a comfortable, healthy and environmentally sustainable place to work and study. 

The BEMOSS®-Plus platform with its advanced learning algorithms addresses two major trends in managing commercial buildings in today’s environment. Firstly, it enables these buildings to operate more efficiently and facilitate participation in electricity markets. Hence, it will result in savings in electricity bills, lower carbon footprints, and enable building owners to earn additional revenues by performing peak demand reduction during grid stress conditions. Secondly, due to its open-architecture nature, BEMOSS®-Plus can integrate a number of emerging IoT and cloud computing technologies, which provides new opportunities for utilizing commercially available low cost sensors/controllers. 

Overall, the proposed solution can potentially bring about benefits to the U.S. economy by reducing energy consumption, improving occupant comfort, participating in electricity markets, and accommodating new technologies. And more importantly, this work created an environment involving a small business (BEM Controls) and an academic institution (Virginia Tech), where theoretical research was applied to develop real-world product designs through mutual consultations and design reviews.  It bridged the knowledge transfer process between BEM Controls (a small business) and Virginia Tech (an institution of higher learning) by facilitating both sides to meet, work, and exchange experiences.
